revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:New Testament people named John}} {{John}}
The [[John (given name)|name '''John''']] (in Greek, {{lang|grc|Ἰωάννης}}) is prominent in the [[New Testament]] and occurs numerous times. Among Jews of this period, the name was one of the most popular, borne by about five percent of men.<ref>{{cite book | title=Jesus and the Eyewitnesses: The Gospels as Eyewitness Testimony | last=Bauckham | first=Richard | authorlink=Richard Bauckham | year=2006 | page=416 | isbn=0802831621 | ref=harv}}</ref> Thus, it has long been debated which Johns are to be identified with which.<ref name="Culpepper">{{cite book | title=John, the Son of Zebedee: The Life of a Legend | year=1994 | at=passim | isbn=0872499626 | last=Culpepper | first=R. Alan | ref=harv}}</ref>
==Mentioned in narrative==
===John, father of Simon Peter===
[[Simon Peter]] is at times called “Simon, son of John”, though in Matthew the text has ''Simon Bariona''.<ref>{{bibleref2|Mt 16:17; Jn 1:42, 21:15–17||!}}.</ref> The latter appears to be untranslated Aramaic, with ''bar'' meaning “son of” and ''Iona'' being Jonah, or according to Bauckham, ''Jôhana‘'', an Aramaized form of ''John''.{{sfnp|Bauckham|2006|p=104}}
===John the Baptist===
{{main|John the Baptist}}
[[John the Baptist]], son of Zechariah, figures prominently in the beginning of each of the four Gospels. The [[Synoptic Gospels]] distinguish him as “the Baptist”, but the [[Gospel of John]] omits this epithet, as no other John is therein mentioned by name. John the Baptist was [[Beheading of St. John the Baptist|beheaded]] during the ministry of Jesus, so in most cases he is easily distinguished from other Johns.
Ford proposes that [[Book of Revelation|Revelation]] originated as prophecy of John the Baptist, expanded by his followers to produce the book in its current form,<ref>{{cite book | title=Revelation | year=1975 | pages=28–37 | isbn=0385008953 | series=The Anchor Bible | volume=38 | last=Ford | first=J. Massyngberde | ref=harv}}</ref> but most scholars reject this theory.<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=b1lDcUkB4GUC&pg=PA26 | title=The Genre of the Book of Revelation from a Source-critical Perspective | year=1989 | pages=26–29 | isbn=3110115182 | series=Beihefte zur Zeitschrift für die neutestamentliche Wissenschaft und die Kunde der älteren Kirche | volume=54 | last=Mazzaferri | first=Frederick David | ref=harv}}</ref>
===John the Apostle===
{{main|John the Apostle}}
[[John the Apostle|John, son of Zebedee]] was one of the [[Twelve Apostles]], along with his brother [[James, son of Zebedee|James]].<ref>{{bibleref2|Mt 10:2; Mk 3:17; Lk 6:14; Acts 1:13||!}}.</ref> This John is mentioned frequently in the [[Synoptic Gospels]], but always (with a lone exception<ref>{{bibleref2|Mk 9:38; Lk 9:49||!}}.</ref>) in company with his brother James<ref>{{bibleref2|Mt 4:21; Mk 1:19; Lk 5:10||!}}; {{bibleref2|Mk 1:29||!}}; {{bibleref2|Lk 9:54||!}}; {{bibleref2|Mt 20:20–24; Mk 10:35–41||!}}; {{bibleref2|Mt 27:56||!}}.</ref> or with [[Saint Peter|Peter]]<ref>{{bibleref2|Lk 22:8||!}}.</ref> or often with both.<ref>{{bibleref2|Mt 17:1; Mk 9:2; Lk 9:28||!}}; {{bibleref2|Mk 5:37; Lk 8:51||!}}; {{bibleref2|Mk 13:3||!}}; {{bibleref2|Mt 26:37; Mk 14:33||!}}.</ref>
In the first eight chapters of [[Acts]], [[Saint Peter|Peter]] is always accompanied by a certain John,<ref>{{bibleref2|Acts|3:1–11, 4:1–22, 8:14|!}}.</ref> who is almost certainly his fellow apostle, and is presumably also the John that Paul elsewhere lists with Peter and James as “pillars”.<ref>{{bibleref2|Gal|2:9|!}}.</ref> But after the execution of his brother James<ref>{{bibleref2|Acts|12:2|!}}.</ref> in 44, this John is never again mentioned.
There are many early indications that James and John were killed together.<ref>{{cite book | url=https://archive.org/details/MN41506ucmf_0 | title=The Enigma of the Fourth Gospel: Its Author and Writer | authorlink=Robert Eisler | year=1938 | pages=58 ff. | last=Eisler | first=Robert | ref=harv}}</ref>{{sfnp|Culpepper|1994|pp=171–174}}<ref>{{cite book | title=Le martyre de Jean l’apôtre | authorlink=Marie-Émile Boismard | year=1996 | isbn=2850210862 | last=Boismard | first=Marie-Émile | ref=harv | series=Cahiers de la Revue biblique | volume=35}}</ref> The response of Jesus to these two, “The cup that I drink you shall drink; and you shall be baptized with the baptism with which I am baptized,”<ref name="martyrdom">{{bibleref2|Mk 10:35–40; Mt 20:20–23||!}}.</ref> has been understood since antiquity as foretelling their [[martyrdom]]. Indeed, [[Papias of Hierapolis|Papias]] (c. 100) records that James and John “were killed by the Jews”,<ref>This point, however, is preserved only in [http://www.chronicon.net/index.php/papias#Philip%20of%20Side Philip of Side] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140910155741/http://www.chronicon.net/index.php/papias#Philip%20of%20Side |date=2014-09-10 }} (c. 435) and in an interpolation in the [http://www.chronicon.net/index.php/papias#George%20Hamartolus ''Chronicology of George Hamartolus''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140910155741/http://www.chronicon.net/index.php/papias#George%20Hamartolus |date=2014-09-10 }} (c. 860).</ref> and early martyrologies record the martyrdom of “John and James the apostles in Jerusalem”.<ref>{{cite journal | jstor=3153028 | title=The Martyrdom of St. John | journal=The American Journal of Theology |date=Oct 1899 | volume=3 | issue=4 | pages=729–740 | last=Badham | first=Francis Pritchett | ref=harv}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | jstor=3153885 | title=The Martyrdom of John the Apostle | journal=The American Journal of Theology |date=Jul 1904 | volume=8 | issue=3 | pages=539–554 | last=Badham | first=Francis Pritchett | ref=harv}}</ref>
Nevertheless, many ancient sources and many modern scholars identify John the Apostle as the author of some or all of the Johannine books, thereby claiming [[Apostle (Christian)|apostolic]] authority for them. Thus, John the Apostle is identified with [[John the Evangelist]], probably also [[John the Elder]], and, with still less certainty, [[John the Revelator]], and also with the John who survived to old age in Ephesus.
===John of the high-priestly family===
This John is mentioned once in passing as present during the trial of Peter and John in Jerusalem, as recorded in [[Acts]]: “On the next day, their rulers, elders, and experts in the law came together in Jerusalem. [[Annas]] the high priest was there, and [[Caiaphas]], John, Alexander, and others who were members of the high priest’s family.”<ref>{{bibleref2|Acts|4:5–7|!}}.</ref> Thus, he is probably distinct from John the Apostle, although some scholars (including the 5th Century writer Nonnus, as well as the [[Gospel of the Nazarenes]]) have suggested that the Zebedees' fishing business made them known to the high priest,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Culpepper|first1=R. Alan|title=John, the Son of Zebedee: The Life of a Legend|publisher=Univ of South Carolina Press.|page=61}}</ref> while others conclude that being fishermen (owning multiple boats) is not synonymous with being poor nor precludes priestly connections, and some argue that the other disciple who was known to the high priest and who ''spoke to the servant-girl on duty there and brought Peter'' in mentioned in John 18:15 is likely to be the same disciple who is never mentioned by name in John's Gospel. However, the Sons of Zebedee are both present in chapter 21 in the count of five plus two (where seven is the 'complete' number) unnamed disciples. The Beloved Disciple is named as such separately; the other is likely Andrew. Which would be the reverse of the first followers identified in chapter 1.
[[Polycrates of Ephesus]] (c. 190) writes that John the Evangelist “was a priest, wearing the [[tzitz|petalon]]”<ref name="Polycrates">Polycrates, ''Ep. ad Vict.'', apud Eusebius, [http://www.ccel.org/ccel/schaff/npnf201.iii.x.xxv.html ''Hist. Eccl.'' 5.24].1–8.</ref>—i.e., specifically that he had served as [[High Priest (Judaism)|High Priest]].{{sfnp|Bauckham|2006|p=447}} In this, he seems to identify the Evangelist with this high-priestly John mentioned in Acts.{{sfnp|Bauckham|2006|pp=438–452}} Some modern scholars make the same identification,{{sfnp|Eisler|1938|pp=36–45}}<ref>{{cite journal | title=L’‘apostolo ed evangelista Giovanni,’ ‘sacerdoto’ levitico | journal=Revista Biblica | year=1990 | volume=38 | issue=4 | pages=451–483 | last=Rigato | first=Maria-Luisa | ref=harv}}</ref> further citing from the Gospel “the other disciple, who was known to the High Priest.”<ref>{{bibleref2|Jn|18:15–16|!}}.</ref>
Although there is no conclusive proof, and early writings such as by Polycrates may be interpretations based on their reading of the gospels,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Culpepper|first1=R. Alan|title=John, the Son of Zebedee: The Life of a Legend|publisher=Univ of South Carolina Press.|page=62}}</ref> there are many theories - as one example: given that Elizabeth, Mary's kinswoman, was a "Daughter of Aaron" (and so had priestly connections), so too would Mary's sister mentioned in John 19:25... and she is mentioned in a way, some suggest, that might indicate she is John's mother.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Morris|first1=Leon|title=The Gospel According to John (The New International Commentary on the New Testament)|date=1995|publisher=Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing Co.|page=666}}</ref>
===John Mark===
{{main|John Mark}}
“[[John Mark|John, called Mark]]” is mentioned several times in Acts.<ref>{{bibleref2|Acts|12:12, 12:25, 13:5, 13:13, 15:37|!}}.</ref> Such use of one Semitic name and another Greek name was a common practice among Jews of the time.{{sfnp|Bauckham|2006|p=83}} He is usually identified with the Mark mentioned in various epistles,<ref>{{bibleref2|1 Pet 5:13; Col 4:10; 2 Tim 4:11; Phil 1:24||!}}.</ref> and with [[Mark the Evangelist]].
This John is occasionally proposed as author of some of the Johannine works as well.{{sfnp|Culpepper|1994|pp=107–108}}<ref name="Dionysius">Dionysius of Alexandria, ''On the Promises'' 2, apud Eusebius, [http://www.ccel.org/ccel/schaff/npnf201.iii.xii.xxvi.html ''Hist. Eccl.'' 7.25].</ref> Tarazi even goes so far as to attribute to him the Gospels of both [[Gospel of Mark|Mark]] and [[Gospel of John|John]] and all the other Johannine books.<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qLkVKM_4UWEC&pg=PA13 | title=Johannine Writings | year=2004 | pages=13–17 | isbn=0881412643 | last=Tarazi | first=Paul Nadim | ref=harv | volume=3 | series=The New Testament: An Introduction}}</ref>
==Johannine literature==
[[File:JohnEvangelistReni.jpg|right|thumb|Guido Reni, ''St. John the Evangelist'', 17th century.]]
{{main|Authorship of the Johannine works}}
Five canonical books of the New Testament are ascribed to John and thus called collectively the ''[[Johannine literature]]'': * The [[Gospel of John]] * The [[First Epistle of John]] * The [[Second Epistle of John]] * The [[Third Epistle of John]] * The [[Book of Revelation]]
Only in Revelation does the text itself name its author as John;<ref>{{bibleref2|Rev|1:1–4, 1:9, 22:8|!}}.</ref> the other Johannine works are ascribed to John only through their attached titles and other external references.
Whether or not these attributions have a basis in historical truth—modern scholars vary widely in their opinions about authorship—the question remains of which John each of these attributions refers to. Since antiquity, many have considered the entire Johannine corpus to be the work of a single author, a certain John of Ephesus, whom many identified with the [[John the Apostle|Apostle John, son of Zebedee]]. On the other hand, this identification and the authorship of individual works have also been disputed since antiquity. Thus, the reputed authors of the Johannine works are conventionally called more explicitly—without prejudice to the issues of actual authorship and of their mutual identification—as follows.
===John the Evangelist===
{{main|John the Evangelist}}
The author of the [[Gospel of John|Gospel]] is termed [[John the Evangelist]].
In the Gospel, the name ''John'' occurs exclusively in reference to [[John the Baptist]], and without that epithet, though “the sons of Zebedee”<ref>{{bibleref2|Jn|21:2|!}}.</ref> (named James and John in the [[Synoptic Gospels|Synoptics]]) are also mentioned once. The Gospel even lacks a list of the [[Twelve Apostles]].
The anonymous “[[disciple whom Jesus loved]]” is identified in the closing verses as the one whose testimony the Gospel bears: “This is the disciple who testifies about these things and has written these things.”<ref>{{bibleref2|Jn|21:20–24|!}}.</ref> Ancient sources invariably identify this disciple with the Evangelist, and many modern scholars agree, though others consider that John the Evangelist fashioned the testimony of the Beloved Disciple into a Gospel, as [[Mark the Evangelist|Mark]] did for [[Saint Peter|Peter]], or hold on other grounds that the two are not identical.
Further identification of the Beloved Disciple and/or the Evangelist with John the Apostle has been variously defended and impugned.<ref>{{cite journal | title=John the Son of Zebedee and the Fourth Gospel | journal=Journal of Biblical Literature |date=Mar 1962 | volume=81 | issue=1 | pages=35–43 | doi=10.2307/3264824 | jstor=3264824 | last=Parker | first=Pierson | ref=harv}}</ref>
Some scholars see the Gospel's “and we know that his testimony is true,”<ref>{{bibleref2|Jn|21:24|!}}.</ref> as indicating a second hand, of a hypothetical “[[John the Redactor]]” or some group of elders certifying the work.{{sfnp|Culpepper|1994|p=94}} Bauckham, however, argues that this is simply the “''we'' of authoritative testimony” of the author himself, used also in the Epistles.<ref>{{bibleref2|3 Jn|1:9–12|!}}; {{bibleref2|1 Jn|1:1–5, 4:11–16|!}}.</ref>{{sfnp|Bauckham|2006|pp=369–383}}
As was an ordinary practice of the time,<ref>{{cite book | title=Encountering the Manuscripts: An Introduction to New Testament Paleography & Textual Criticism | year=2005 | pages=4–9 | isbn=0805431454 | last=Comfort | first=Philip | ref=harv}}</ref>{{sfnp|Bauckham|2006|p=359}} the Evangelist may have employed an [[amanuensis]]. Apocryphal sources of about the 5th century variously name [[Prochorus]],{{sfnp|Culpepper|1994|pp=269–270|ps=, from the [[Acts of John|Acts of John of Prochorus]].}} [[Saint Timothy|Timothy]],{{sfnp|Culpepper|1994|pp=359|ps=, from the [[Acts of Timothy]].}} or even [[Papias of Hierapolis|Papias]],{{sfnp|Culpepper|1994|pp=165–167|ps=, from the Anti-Marcionite prologues.}} and modern scholars have suggested others.{{sfnp|Eisler|1938|pp=178–184}}<ref>{{cite journal | url=http://www.biblicalstudies.org.uk/pdf/bsac/1905_484.pdf | title=The Hand of Apollos in the Fourth Gospel | journal=Bibliotheca Sacra | year=1905 | volume=62 | pages=484–99 | last=Rollins | first=George S. | ref=harv}}</ref>
===John the Elder===
{{main|John the Elder}}
The short [[Second Epistle of John|second]] and [[Third Epistle of John|third]] epistles are addressed “From the Elder”.<ref>{{bibleref2|2 Jn 1:1; 3 Jn 1:1||!}}.</ref> On this basis, the author is termed [[John the Elder]] or John the Presbyter (''presbyter'' being Greek for ''elder'').
[[Papias of Hierapolis|Papias]] (c. 100) refers to a certain “John the Elder, a disciple of the Lord”, one of the “elders” he had listened to, and from whose sayings he drew in his five-book ''Exegesis'', now lost. Papias goes on to refer to him simply as “the Elder”. Most see Papias as referring to the same John, at least, who penned the epistles.<ref>{{cite book | title=The Johannine Question | authorlink=Martin Hengel | year=1989 | pages=24–45 | isbn=033400795X | last=Hengel | first=Martin | ref=harv}}</ref>
In later centuries, some saw the address from “the Elder” in the second and third epistles as possibly indicating a different author than the other Johannine works, which cast doubt on their apostolic authority and therefore on their [[New Testament canon|canonicity]].<ref>Origen, apud Eusebius, [http://www.ccel.org/ccel/schaff/npnf201.iii.xi.xxv.html ''Hist. Eccl.'' 6.25].10.</ref><ref>Eusebius, [http://www.ccel.org/ccel/schaff/npnf201.iii.viii.xxv.html ''Hist. Eccl.'' 3.25].3.</ref><ref>Jerome, [http://www.ccel.org/ccel/schaff/npnf203.v.iii.xx.html ''De Vir. Illustr.'' 18].</ref>
===John the Revelator===
[[File:Seven churches of asia.svg|right|thumb|Patmos and the seven churches of Asia.]]
{{main|John of Patmos }}
The author of [[Book of Revelation|Revelation]] is variously termed John the Revelator, John the Divine, John the Theologian, or [[John of Patmos]].
The text of Revelation identifies its author thus: “I, John, your brother and the one who shares with you in the persecution, kingdom, and endurance that are in Jesus, was on the island called [[Patmos]] because of the word of God and the testimony about Jesus.”<ref>{{bibleref2|Rev|1:9|NET}}.</ref> Patmos was an island near [[Ephesus]], and Revelation begins with letters addressed to the [[seven churches of Asia]], which were Ephesus and other nearby cities.
[[Dionysius of Alexandria]] (c. 250) closely criticized Revelation and concluded that it was starkly different from the Gospel and First Epistle (which Dionysius regarded as both the work of John the Apostle) in grammar, style, content, and anonymity, and thus could hardly be the work of the same author, but must have been written by another John, for “there are two monuments in Ephesus, each bearing the name of John.”<ref name="Dionysius"/> Many modern scholars have concurred with this analysis, but others find striking similarities on closer inspection and attribute the stylistic differences to the Evangelist's use of an [[amanuensis]].<ref>{{cite book | title=The Book of Revelation: An Introduction and Commentary | authorlink=Leon Morris | year=1987 | pages=27–34 | isbn=0802802737 | last=Morris | first=Leon | ref=harv | series=Tyndale New Testament Commentaries | volume=20}}</ref>{{sfnp|Culpepper|1994|pp=130–134}}
The ancient scholars who accepted Revelation as authentic, however, invariably identified its author as John the Evangelist.<ref>{{cite book | title=Patmos in the Reception History of the Apocalypse | year=2013 | pages=28 ff. | isbn=0199674205 | last=Boxall | first=Ian | ref=harv}}</ref> Our earliest and most reliable informant is [[Irenaeus]] (c. 180), who knew John's personal disciples while in [[Smyrna]]. Irenaeus firmly identifies the Revelator with the Evangelist<ref name="Irenaeus-authors">Irenaeus, ''Adv. Haer.'' [http://www.ccel.org/ccel/schaff/anf01.ix.iv.xvii.html 3.16].5, 8; [http://www.ccel.org/ccel/schaff/anf01.ix.vi.xxi.html 4.20].11.</ref> and tells us that he remained with the Church in Ephesus until the time of [[Trajan]] (98–117).<ref name="Irenaeus-Trajan">Irenaeus, [http://www.hypotyposeis.org/synoptic-problem/2004/11/external-evidence-irenaeus.html ''Adv. Haer.'' 2.22.5, 3.3.4].</ref> The Revelator was still publicly active until the close of [[Domitian]]’s reign (81–96), as Irenaeus says:<ref>Irenaeus, [http://www.ccel.org/ccel/schaff/anf01.ix.vii.xxxi.html ''Adv. Haer.'' 5.30].3.</ref>
{{quotation|For if it were necessary that the [[Antichrist]]’s name should be distinctly revealed in this present time, it would have been announced by him who beheld the apocalyptic vision. For he {{bracket|or ''it''?}} was seen no very long time since, but almost in our day, towards the end of Domitian’s reign.}}
From Irenaeus’ ambiguous syntax, some later writers inferred that the exile to Patmos occurred under Domitian, though others explicitly ascribed it to [[Nero]] (54–68); modern scholars still debate which is more likely.<ref>{{cite book | url=http://www.preteristarchive.com/Books/pdf/1989_gentry_before-jerusalem-fell.pdf | title=Before Jerusalem Fell | authorlink=Kenneth Gentry | year=1989 | pages=45–67 | isbn=0930464206 | last=Gentry | first=Kenneth L. | ref=harv}}</ref>
[[Clement of Alexandria]], a contemporary of Irenaeus, tells an anecdote of John and the young robber captain, which opens with:<ref>Clement of Alexandria, [http://www.ccel.org/ccel/schaff/anf02.vi.v.html ''Quis dives salvetur''] 42.</ref>
{{quotation|When, on the tyrant’s death, he returned to Ephesus from the isle of Patmos, he went away, being invited, to the contiguous territories of the nations, here to appoint bishops, there to set in order whole Churches, there to ordain such as were marked out by the Spirit.}}
So again the Revelator is identified with the Bishop of Ephesus, about whom ancient sources have much to say.
==John of Ephesus==
Patristic sources from as early as the 2nd century widely attest to a certain John, a disciple of Jesus, who lived to old age in [[Ephesus]], and to whom all the Johannine works are ascribed.{{sfnp|Bauckham|2006|pp=438, 453}}
Whether such a man existed, which works he wrote, whether this figure has been confused or conflated with a second John, and whether he is identical with John son of Zebedee or any other John in the New Testament are all matters of intense controversy.<ref name="Culpepper" />
[[File:Christ and St. John (Boston Public Library).jpg|right|thumb|Ary Scheffer, ''Christ and St. John'', 19th century]]
[[Irenaeus]] (c. 180), who cites from [[Papias of Hierapolis|Papias]] and “the elders” and also personally knew [[Polycarp of Smyrna]], another disciple of John of Ephesus, is widely considered the most reliable authority we have on this John. In our first extant description of all four Gospels, Irenaeus concludes:<ref>Irenaeus, [http://www.hypotyposeis.org/synoptic-problem/2004/11/external-evidence-irenaeus.html ''Adv. Haer.'' 3.1.1].</ref>
{{quotation|Finally John, the disciple of the Lord, who had lain on his breast,<ref>{{bibleref2|Jn|13:25, 21:20|!}}.</ref> himself also published a Gospel, while he was residing at Ephesus of Asia.}}
Here, John the Evangelist is clearly identified with the [[Beloved Disciple]] and located in Ephesus. Elsewhere Irenaeus unmistakably cites this same John as author of the Epistles and Revelation as well.<ref name="Irenaeus-authors"/><ref>{{cite book | title=The Johannine Corpus in the Early Church | year=2004 | pages=97–101 | isbn=0199264589 | last=Hill | first=Charles E. | ref=harv}}</ref> Irenaeus also speaks of the aged John surviving in Ephesus until the time of [[Trajan]] (98–117),<ref name="Irenaeus-Trajan"/> which would be about 70 years after the [[Crucifixion of Jesus#Chronology of the crucifixion|Crucifixion]].
[[Polycrates of Ephesus]] (c. 190) is another especially respected source on John, writing of his own relative and predecessor (following the [[Philip the Apostle]]):<ref name="Polycrates"/>
{{quotation|There is John also, he who leaned back on the Lord’s breast, who was a priest wearing the [[tzitz|petalon]], both witness and teacher. He has fallen asleep at Ephesus.}}
Polycrates is in accord with Irenaeus, but seems to additionally identify John with the high-priestly John in Acts.{{sfnp|Bauckham|2006|pp=438–452}}
The earliest evidence on the identity of this John is from [[Papias of Hierapolis]], a “hearer of John”<ref>Irenaeus, [http://www.newadvent.org/fathers/0103533.htm ''Adv. Haer.'' 5.33].4.</ref> writing c. 100,<ref>{{cite journal | url=http://www.etsjets.org/files/JETS-PDFs/26/26-2/26-2-pp181-191_JETS.pdf | title=The Date of Papias: A Reassessment | last=Yarbrough | first=Robert W. | journal=Journal of the Evangelical Theological Society |date=Jun 1983 | volume=26 | issue=2 | pages=181–191 | ref=harv}}</ref> whose work survives only in fragments quoted by others. Papias writes:<ref>Eusebius, [http://www.ccel.org/ccel/schaff/npnf201.iii.viii.xxxix.html ''Hist. Eccl.'' 3.39].4. Translation from {{harvtxt|Bauckham|2006}}, p. 417.</ref>
{{quotation|And if by chance anyone who had been in attendance on the elders should come my way, I inquired about the words of the elders—what Andrew or Peter had said, or Philip, or Thomas or James, or John or Matthew or any other of the Lord’s disciples, and whatever Aristion and the elder John, the Lord’s disciples, were saying.}}
So, Papias refers first to John the Apostle, listed with his brother and others of the Twelve, whose words the elders had handed down to him, and then to John the Elder, another disciple of Jesus, who was himself still being heard. Though some have interpreted these as two references to the same John,<ref>{{cite book | title=John: Evangelist and Interpreter | authorlink=Stephen Smalley | year=1978 | pages=73–74 | isbn=0853642141 | last=Smalley | first=Stephen Stewart | ref=harv}}</ref> Bauckham argues that Papias is clearly distinguishing them.{{sfnp|Bauckham|2006|pp=412–437}} Papias then goes on to cite “the Elder” (just as the Second and Third Epistles are addressed from) on the origins of the Gospels of Mark and Matthew at least,<ref>Eusebius, [http://www.ccel.org/ccel/schaff/npnf201.iii.viii.xxxix.html ''Hist. Eccl.'' 3.39].15.</ref> and also to cite from the First Epistle and Revelation.
Papias’ account of the origin of the Gospel of John is apparently paraphrased and expanded by Eusebius<ref>Eusebius, [http://www.ccel.org/ccel/schaff/npnf201.iii.viii.xxiv.html ''Hist. Eccl.'' 3.24].5–13.</ref>{{sfnp|Bauckham|2006|pp=433–437}}<ref>{{cite journal | title=What Papias Said About John (and Luke): A ‘New’ Papian Fragment | journal=Journal of Theological Studies | year=1998 | volume=49 | issue=2 | pages=582–629 | doi=10.1093/jts/49.2.582 | last=Hill | first=Charles E. | ref=harv}}</ref> and is most likely the source for the [[Muratorian Canon]] (c. 170) when it says:<ref>[http://www.chronicon.net/index.php/papias#Hypothetical%20Fragments Papias: Hypothetical Fragments] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140910155741/http://www.chronicon.net/index.php/papias |date=2014-09-10 }}.</ref>{{sfnp|Bauckham|2006|pp=425–432}}
{{quotation|The fourth of the gospels is of John, one of the disciples. To his fellow-disciples and bishops, who were encouraging him, he said: “Fast with me today for three days, and whatever will be revealed to each of us, let us tell to one another.” The same night it was revealed to [[Andrew the Apostle|Andrew]], one of the apostles, that all should certify what John wrote in his own name.… Why, then, is it remarkable that John so constantly brings forth single points even in his epistles, saying of himself, “What we have seen with our eyes and heard with our ears and our hands have handled, these we write to you”?<ref>{{bibleref2|1 John|1:1, 4|!}}.</ref> Thus he professes himself not only an eyewitness and hearer but also a writer of all the miracles of our Lord in order.}}
The ''[[Acts of John]]'', an apocryphal [[Christian Gnosticism|Gnostic]] work thought to have been composed around the late 2nd century, paints a rich, full narrative about John that was profoundly influential on later sources. Here we find the first explicit identification with the son of Zebedee, the story of the attempted [[death by boiling|execution by boiling oil]] also reported by [[Tertullian]],<ref>Tertullian, [http://www.ccel.org/ccel/schaff/anf03.v.iii.xxxvi.html ''De Praes. Haer.'' 36].</ref> the manner of John's natural death, and a great deal more.{{sfnp|Culpepper|1994|pp=232–251}} From the 3rd century onward, legends about John abound, with little hope of untangling any truth from the fiction.
It is clear that John of Ephesus was regarded from the earliest times as a personal disciple of Jesus and a crucial witness to his life, an author of scripture, an apostle, and a great leader among the churches of Asia; whether he was also the son of Zebedee, one of the Twelve Apostles, is much more doubtful. No such identification is explicit in the early sources, apart from the clearly apocryphal, until the middle of the 3rd century. At most, John of Ephesus is occasionally called ''apostle'', but in those cases the term is certainly not confined to the Twelve, and when mentioned with one of the Twelve Apostles, the Evangelist is in fact usually called a ''disciple'' by contrast.{{sfnp|Bauckham|2006|pp=458–463}} Bauckham argues that Papias distinguishes them and that the words of Polycrates even preclude such identification,{{sfnp|Bauckham|2006|pp=444–452}} and echos of this distinction linger in a few later sources.<ref>{{cite journal | url=http://www.earlychurch.org.uk/pdf/evangelist_bruce.pdf | title=Some Notes on the Fourth Evangelist | journal=The Evangelical Quarterly | year=1944 | volume=16 | pages=101–109 | last=Bruce | first=F. F. | ref=harv}}</ref> Among the orthodox, [[Origen]] is the first to explicitly accept the identification,{{sfnp|Culpepper|1994|p=358}} which requires him to reconcile the tradition of John's natural death<ref>{{cite book | title=Polycarp and John: The Harris Fragments and Their Challenge to the Literary Tradition | year=1999 | pages=134–135 | isbn=0268038511 | last=Weidmann | first=Frederick W. | ref=harv}}</ref><ref>Jerome, ''Comm. in Matt.'' 20.23, apud {{harvtxt|Culpepper|1994}}, p. 206.</ref> with the prophecy of John's martyrdom<ref name="martyrdom"/> by seeing the latter fulfilled in his temporary exile to Patmos.<ref>Origen, ''In Matt.'' 16.6, apud {{harvtxt|Boxall|2013}}, p. 36.</ref> On the other hand, after this point the identification was almost universally accepted in antiquity.{{sfnp|Bauckham|2006|p=452}}
On whether or not John of Ephesus is to be identified with any of the Johns in the New Testament narrative—the son of Zebedee, the high-priestly John, or even John Mark—modern scholars remain divided.<ref name="Culpepper" />

revision.text:
The '''paradox of the pesticides''' is a [[paradox]] that states that applying [[pesticide]] to a [[pest (organism)|pest]] may end up increasing the [[abundance (ecology)|abundance]] of the pest if the pesticide upsets natural predator–prey dynamics in the ecosystem.
== Lotka–Volterra equation == To describe the paradox of the pesticides mathematically, the [[Lotka–Volterra equation]], a set of first-order, nonlinear, [[differential equations]], which are frequently used to describe predator–prey interactions, can be modified to account for the additions of pesticides into the predator–prey interactions.
=== Without pesticides === The variables represent the following:
: <math>\begin{align} H & = \text{the prey population at a given time} \\ P & = \text{the predator population at a given time} \\ c & = \text{the capture constant} \\ r & = \text{the rate of growth of the prey population} \\ a & = \text{the fraction of prey energy assimilated by the predator and turned into new predators} \\ m & = \text{predator mortality rate} \\ \end{align}</math>
The following two equations are the original [[Lotka–Volterra equation]], which describe the rate of change of each respective population as a function of the population of the other organism:
: <math>\begin{align} \frac{dH}{dt} & = rH - cHP \\ \frac{dP}{dt} & = acHP - mP \\ \end{align}</math>
By setting each equation to zero and thus assuming a stable population, a graph of two lines ([[isocline]]s) can be made to find the equilibrium point, the point at which both interacting populations are stable.
These are the isoclines for the two above equations:
: <math> P=\frac{r}{c} \quad \text{and} \quad H=\frac{m}{ac}</math>
=== Accounting for pesticides ===
[[File:Isoclines-2.png|thumb|right|300px|Predator–prey isoclines before and after pesticide application. Pest abundance has increased.]]
Now, to account for the difference in the population dynamics of the predator and prey that occurs with the addition of pesticides, variable ''q'' is added to represent the per capita rate at which both species are killed by the pesticide. The original Lotka–Volterra equations change to be as follows:
: <math>\begin{align} \frac{dH}{dt} & = H(r-cP-q) \\ \frac{dP}{dt} & = P(acH-m-q) \\ \end{align}</math>
Solving the isoclines as was done above, the following equations represent the two lines with the intersection that represents the new equilibrium point. These are the new isoclines for the populations:
: <math> P=\frac{r-q}{c} \quad \text{and} \quad H=\frac{m+q}{ac}</math>
As one can see from the new isoclines, the new equilibrium will have a higher H value and a lower P value so the number of prey will increase while the number of predator decreases. Thus, prey, which is normally the targeted by the pesticide, is actually being benefited instead of harmed by the pesticide.
A credible, simple alternative to the Lotka-Volterra predator–prey model and its common prey dependent generalizations is the ratio dependent or [[Arditi–Ginzburg equations|Arditi–Ginzburg model]].<ref>Arditi, R. and Ginzburg, L.R. 1989. [http://life.bio.sunysb.edu/ee/ginzburglab/Coupling%20in%20Predator-Prey%20Dynamics%20-%20Arditi%20and%20Ginzburg,%201989.pdf Coupling in predator–prey dynamics: ratio dependence]. ''Journal of Theoretical Biology'' 139: 311-326.</ref> The two are the extremes of the spectrum of predator interference models. According to the authors of the alternative view, the data show that true interactions in nature are so far from the Lotka-Volterra extreme on the interference spectrum that the model can simply be discounted as wrong. They are much closer to the ratio-dependent extreme, so if a simple model is needed, one can use the Arditi–Ginzburg model as the first approximation.<ref>Arditi, R. and Ginzburg, L.R. 2012. ''How Species Interact: Altering the Standard View on Trophic Ecology''. Oxford University Press, New York, NY.</ref>
== Empirical evidence ==
The paradox has been documented repeatedly throughout the history of pest management. Predatory [[mites]], for example, naturally prey upon [[phytophagous]] mites, which are common pests in apple orchards. Spraying the orchards kills both mites, but the effect of diminished predation is larger than that of the pesticide, and phytophagous mites increase in abundance.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Lester | first1 = P. J. | last2 = Thistlewood | first2 = H. M. A. | last3 = Harmsen | first3 = R. | year = 1998 | title = The Effects of Refuge Size and Number on Acarine Predator–Prey Dynamics in a Pesticide-Disturbed Apple Orchard | journal = Journal of Applied Ecology | volume = 35 | issue = 2 | pages = 323–331 | jstor =2405131 | doi=10.1046/j.1365-2664.1998.00304.x }}</ref>
The effect has also been seen on rice, as documented by the [[International Rice Research Institute]], which noted significant declines in pest populations when they stopped applying pesticide.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Sackville Hamilton | first1 = Henry |date=January–March 2008 | title = The Pesticide Paradox | journal = Rice Today | issue = 1 | pages = 32–33 | accessdate = 3 February 2011 | url = http://beta.irri.org/news/images/stories/ricetoday/7-1/SS_pesticide%20paradox.pdf }}</ref>
== Related phenomena ==
Recent studies suggest that such a paradox might not be necessarily caused by the reduction of the predator population by harvesting itself, for example, by a pesticide. The host population is reduced at the moment of harvesting, and simultaneously, the intraspecific density effect is weakened.<ref name="Matsuoka, T. 2008">{{Cite journal | last1 = Matsuoka | first1 = T. | last2 = Seno | first2 = H. | doi = 10.1016/j.jtbi.2008.01.024 | title = Ecological balance in the native population dynamics may cause the paradox of pest control with harvesting | journal = Journal of Theoretical Biology | volume = 252 | issue = 1 | pages = 87–97 | year = 2008 | pmid = 18329048| pmc = }}</ref> [[Intraspecific competition]] accounts for the competition between individuals of a same species. When the population density is high and resources are consequently relatively scarce, each individual has less access to resources to invest energy in growth, survivorship and reproduction. That causes a decrease in the survival rate or an increase in mortality.
Intraspecific competition increases with density. One could expect that a population decrease (due to harvesting, for example) will decrease the population density and reduce intraspecific competition, which would lead to a lower death rate among the prey population.
Studies show also that direct effects on the predator population, through harvesting of the prey, are not necessary to observe the paradox.<ref name="Matsuoka, T. 2008"/> Harvesting of prey has been shown to trigger a reduction in the predator’s reproduction rate, which lowers the equilibrium predator level. Thus, changes in [[Biological life cycle|life history]] strategy (patterns of growth, reproduction and survivorship) can also contribute to the paradox.
Seemingly the paradox can be accounted for by the indirect effects of harvesting on the native ecological interactions of prey and predator: reduction of intraspecific density effect for the prey and reduction of the reproductive rate for the predator. The former increases the population recovery of the prey, and the latter decreases the equilibrium population level for the predator.
== Solutions ==
To deal with the paradox, growers may turn to [[integrated pest management]] (IPM),<ref>"Michigan Tech Blog: 6 Advantages of Integrated Pest Management" https://hub.sfi.mtu.edu/members/3137/blog/2015/Jan/5-advantages-of-integrated-pest-management</ref> an ecological approach to pest control that accounts for the interactions between pests and their environment.<ref>U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. “Integrated Pest Management (IPM) Principles,” http://www.epa.gov/opp00001/factsheets/ipm.htm (2008).</ref> There is not only one way to practice IPM, but some methods include using mechanical trapping devices or increasing the abundance of natural predators.<ref>U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. “Pesticides and Food: What ‘Integrated Pest Management’ Means,” http://www.epa.gov/pesticides/food/ipm.htm (2007).</ref>
IPM is also often touted for its environmental and health benefits, as it avoids the use of chemical pesticides.
== See also == * [[List of paradoxes]] * [[Paradox of enrichment]]: Increasing the food available to an ecosystem may introduce instability, and may even lead to extinction.

The '''Philosophy Learning and Teaching Organization''' (PLATO) is a non-profit membership orgsanization established to support the introduction of philosophy to pre-college students (K-12). It was established in 2009 by the American Philosophical Association's Committee on Pre-College-Instruction in Philosophy, and became an independent non-profit organization in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.apaonline.org/group/precollege |title=APA website, Committee on Pre-College Instruction |accessdate=2 August 2014}}</ref> PLATO sponsors the annual journal ''[[Questions: Philosophy for Young People]]''. The organization's memberships are managed by the [[Philosophy Documentation Center]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://plato-philosophy.org/who-we-are/membership/ |title=Membership information, Philosophy Learning and Teaching Organization |accessdate=2 August 2014}}</ref>
==Online resources for members== Members have online access to the following publications to support their research: * ''[[Questions: Philosophy for Young People]]'', 2001–present * ''[[Teaching Ethics]]'', 2001–present * ''[[Teaching Philosophy]]'', 1975–present * ''Demonstrating Philosophy'' (anthology), 1988 * ''Teaching New Histories of Philosophy'' (conference proceeding), 2004 * ''Teaching Philosophy Today'' (anthology, 2nd edition), 2012 * ''The Journal of Pre-College Philosophy'', Volumes 1-2 (1975-1977)> * ''The Journal of Critical Analysis'', Volumes 1-9 (1969-1992)

The relationship between '''religion and [[HIV/AIDS]]''' is complicated, and often controversial. Controversies have mainly revolved around [[LGBT]] people and [[condom]] use.
==Religious attitudes towards HIV-positive people and AIDS== ===Islam===
The question of Islam and [[AIDS]] has arisen in recent years as the [[HIV/AIDS]] epidemic has grown stronger, with awareness and efforts to prevent the spread of the disease.<ref name="Tackling AIDS">{{cite web|url=http://www.islamonline.net/servlet/Satellite?c=Article_C&cid=1157962465531&pagename=Zone-English-HealthScience%2FHSELayout |title=Tackling AIDS Through Islam? |author=Najma Mohamed |work=Islam Online |accessdate=26 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070529085511/http://www.islamonline.net/servlet/Satellite?c=Article_C&cid=1157962465531&pagename=Zone-English-HealthScience%2FHSELayout |archivedate=May 29, 2007 }}</ref> Many Muslims view the AIDS epidemic through what is called the “prism of sin”, and as the consequence of sinful behavior, such as [[prostitution]], sex with multiple partners or [[promiscuity]].<ref name="Tackling AIDS"/> Awareness of the HIV/AIDS epidemic is growing among the Muslim community and efforts are being initiated to prevent its spread. The Muslim Awareness Programme (MAP), based in South Africa is a faith-based organization that promotes HIV/AIDS prevention strategies based on the moral teachings of Islam. These activities include the promotion of [[abstinence]] from all sexual activity outside marriage; refraining from drug use, and instilling faithfulness within marriage. According to most Muslims, the key to combating to the HIV/AIDS epidemic is prevention.{{citation needed|date=August 2017}} In their view, the Islamic position on morality, chastity and the sanctity of marriage needs to be shared with the world. Islam cites sex with multiple partners, sex outside marriage, other promiscuous sexual behaviors and [[homosexuality]] as immoral and as a result of this some Muslims consider this behavior the main cause of HIV/AIDS, believing that promoting abstinence, chastity, and intramarital sex is the key to ending or at least containing the epidemic.
===Judaism and Jewish thinkers=== As opposed to the Catholic Church and some other denominations or religions, today, there isn't any central Jewish religious authority that is acceptable by vast majority of religious Jews or by most Jewish religious movements.
[[Orthodox Judaism]] links between immoral sexual behavior and AIDS. [[Immanuel Jakobovits, Baron Jakobovits]], former Chief Rabbi of England, a prominent figure in 20th century Jewish medical ethics<ref>[[Immanuel Jakobovits, Baron Jakobovits]]</ref> maintains in his article "Halachic Perspectives on AIDS" that "... from my reading of Jewish sources, it would appear that under no circumstances would we be justified in branding the incidence of the disease (...) as punishment ... we have not the vision, that would enable us to link, as an assertion of certainty, any form of human travail, grief, bereavement or suffering in general with shortcomings of a moral nature... It is one thing to speak of a consequence, and it is quite another thing to speak of a punishment ... if you warn a child not to play with fire, lest he gets burnt, and the child then gets burnt, then the burning may not be a punishment for not listening, but it certainly is a consequence. ... I think we should declare in very plain and explicit terms indicating that our society violated some of the norms of the Divine Law, and of the natural law, and that as a consequence we pay a price, and an exceedingly heavy price. This certainly is Jewish doctrine ..."<ref>[http://www.medethics.org.il/articles/JME/JMEB2/JMEB2.14.asp] ASSIA – ''Jewish Medical Ethics'', Vol. 2, No. 1, January 1991, pp. 3–8</ref>
In [[Jewish Orthodox]] society, having AIDS is considered a mark of disgrace.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jewish Responses to HIV: A Mitzvah|url=http://www.thebody.com/content/art56481.html|work=TheBody.com|accessdate=27 January 2014|author=Alana Krivo-Kaufman}}</ref>
[[Conservative Judaism|Conservative]] and [[Reform Judaism]] emphasize the importance of ''[[bikur cholim]]'', the responsibility to care for the sick: :"The [[United Synagogue of Conservative Judaism]] calls upon all of its congregations to reach out to individuals infected with the AIDS virus, their families and their friends by providing acceptance, comfort, counseling, and sympathetic and empathetic listening; and ... affirms that those infected with the AIDS virus must be protected from all forms of [[Discrimination against people with HIV/AIDS|illegal discrimination]], such as discriminatory housing, employment, health care delivery services and synagogue services."<ref>{{cite web|title=United Synagogue Resolution On AIDS|url=http://www.jewishlasvegas.com/page.aspx?id=12085|publisher=The Jewish Federation of Las Vegas|accessdate=27 June 2013|author=United Synagogue of Conservative Judaism|year=1991 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110920230253/http://www.jewishlasvegas.com/page.aspx?id=12085 |archivedate=20 September 2011}}</ref> Rabbi Marla J. Feldman, Director of the Joint Commission on Social Action of the Union for Reform Judaism: "However, we must look past the incomprehensible statistics and long lists of facts and recognize the Divine image within the faces of the individual people infected and affected by this disease. The responsibility lies with each of us to protect and care for these victims ..."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rac.org/Articles/index.cfm?id=1999&pge_prg_id=13740 |publisher=Religious Action Center of Reform Judaism|title=Reform Jewish Leader Mourns AIDS Deaths and Calls for Comprehensive HIV/AIDS Prevention |accessdate=April 20, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101127211945/http://rac.org/Articles/index.cfm?id=1999&pge_prg_id=13740 |archivedate=27 November 2010}}</ref>
=== Christianity === Many Christian charities provide services for people living with HIV/AIDS.{{citation needed|date=August 2017}} One example is the [[DREAM (AIDS therapy program)|"Drug Resources Enhancement against Aids and Malnutrition" (DREAM)]], program promoted by the [[Christian]] [[Community of Sant'Egidio]].
[[Jerry Falwell]] regularly linked the [[AIDS pandemic]] to LGBT issues and stated, "AIDS is not just God's punishment for homosexuals, it is God's punishment for the society that tolerates homosexuals."<ref name="Falwell">{{cite web|url = http://www.milforddailynews.com/opinion/x1987843539|title=Press: The Sad Legacy of Jerry Falwell|accessdate=2007-05-18|last= Press|first = Bill |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080430144811/http://www.milforddailynews.com/opinion/x1987843539 |archivedate=30 April 2008}}</ref>
=== Hinduism === [[Hinduism]] has shown support for research aimed at curing HIV/AIDS, and care for those affected by HIV/AIDS.<ref name="Tackling AIDS"/>
==Prevention== ===Catholicism=== {{main|Catholic Church and AIDS}} The Catholic Church opposes [[condom]] use between heterosexual couples because it is an artificial form of [[contraception]] that does not rely on the functions of the body (and thus also God's will) itself as to whether a conception will occur or not, and the Church believes it also serves to implicitly and inexcusably encourage premarital and extramarital sexuality (and recourse to abortion if the condom fails).{{citation needed|date=August 2017}}
[[Pope John Paul II]] strongly opposed the use of artificial birth control, and rejected the use of condoms to prevent the spread of HIV.<ref name="John Paul II and condoms">{{cite web|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,2144,1979145,00.html|title=Catholic Church to Ease Ban on Condom Use|date=24 April 2006|publisher=© 2006, 2009 Deutsche Welle|accessdate=12 January 2009}}</ref> [[Pope Benedict XVI]] stated in 2005 that condoms were not a sufficient solution to the AIDS crisis,<ref>{{cite news|publisher=BBC News|title=Pope rejects condoms for Africa|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4081276.stm | date=2005-06-10 | accessdate=2010-05-22}}</ref> but then in 2009 claimed that AIDS "cannot be overcome through the distribution of condoms, which even aggravates the problems."<ref>{{cite news|publisher=The Telegraph|title=Pope Benedict XVI: condoms make Aids crisis worse|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/vaticancityandholysee/5005357/Pope-Benedict-XVI-condoms-make-Aids-crisis-worse.html | date=2009-03-17 | accessdate=2011-05-22}}</ref> The [[Moscow Patriarchate]] gave support to Benedict XVI's position.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.catholic.org/news/international/africa/story.php?id=32756 |title=Moscow Patriarchate Backs Pope's Stance on Condoms |publisher=Zenit News Agency |date=21 March 2009}}</ref> In response to Benedict XVI's statements, the [[United Church of Christ]] issued a statement encouraging condom distribution at places of worship.<ref name="UCC and condoms">[http://www.ucc.org/news/uccs-health-advocates-press.html UCC’s health advocates press for increased condom distribution]</ref>
On November 20, 2010, when questioned about the rampant HIV spread in Africa, [[Pope Benedict XVI]] suggested that the use of condoms in male prostitution is not a moral solution to stopping AIDS, but could represent a first step in assuming moral responsibility "in the intention of reducing the risk of infection."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20101120/ap_on_re_eu/eu_pope_condoms |title=Pope says some condom use first step of morality |website=Yahoo News |publisher=Associated Press |date=20 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101121121202/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20101120/ap_on_re_eu/eu_pope_condoms |archivedate=21 November 2010}}</ref> Vatican City clarifies, after Benedict's statement sows confusion, that the position of the Church on condoms has not changed. It is merely a statement that in homosexual relations, where unnatural contraception is not the main concern, condoms can be seen as moral responsibility in preventing HIV infections.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/religion/2010-11-20-pope-condoms_N.htm | work=USA Today | title=Vatican clarifies pope's condom comments: Nothing's changed | date=2010-11-23}}</ref> On November 23, 2010, Benedict furthermore stated that the concept of condoms as a lesser evil in preventing HIV infections can be applied to women as well. The use of condoms is the first step in taking responsibility and attempting to prevent the infection of one's partner. The Pope does not say anything about condoms being acceptable as unnatural birth control, only as a responsible approach.<ref>[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/40331930/ns/world_news-europe]</ref>
===Buddhism=== In Thailand, some Buddhist monks encourage the use of condoms for HIV prevention.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.buddhistchannel.tv/index.php?id=52,3702,0,0,1,0|title=Buddhist Monk Embraces Condoms|date=2007-02-07|accessdate=2009-10-25}}</ref> As part of [[Mechai Viravaidya]]'s pro-condom campaign, Buddhist monks have offered blessed condoms for couples.<ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/rxforsurvival/series/champions/mechai_viravaidya.html|publisher=[[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]]|title = Global Health Champions: Mechai Viravaidya|accessdate=2009-10-25}}</ref>
==Treatment== The work of some Christian ministries has affected the treatment of AIDS. According to the African Health Policy Network, some churches in [[London]] claim that prayer will cure AIDS and the [[London Borough of Hackney|Hackney]]-based Centre for the Study of Sexual Health and HIV reports that several people have stopped taking their medication, sometimes on the direct advice of their [[pastor]], leading to a number of deaths.<ref name=BBC18102011>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-14406818|title=Church HIV prayer cure claims 'cause three deaths'|date=18 October 2011|accessdate=18 October 2011|publisher=[[BBC News]]}}</ref> The [[Synagogue Church Of All Nations]] advertise an "anointing water" to promote God's healing, although the group deny advising people to stop taking medication,<ref name=BBC18102011 /> and US [[patent application]] 2001051133 similarly suggests that intravenous pure distilled water will eradicate HIV through the mercy of God.<ref>{{Cite patent|US|2001051133|status=application}}</ref> Other Christian churches actively distribute HIV/AIDS medication.{{citation needed|date=August 2017}}
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}

'''Rule by decree''' is a style of governance allowing quick, unchallenged creation of law by a single person or group, and is used primarily by [[dictator]]s, [[absolute monarch]]s and [[military]] leaders.
The expression is also sometimes used when describing actions of democratic governments that are perceived to unduly bypass parliamentarian or popular scrutiny.
Rule by [[decree]] allows the ruler to arbitrarily create law, without approval by a [[legislative]] assembly.
When states of emergency such as [[martial law]] are in place, rule by decree is common. While rule by decree is easily susceptible to the whims and corruption of the person in power, it is also highly efficient: a law can take weeks or months to pass in a legislature, but can be created with the stroke of a pen by a leader ruling by decree. This is what makes it valuable in emergency situations. Thus, it is allowed by many [[constitutions]], among which is the [[Constitution of France|French Constitution]], [[Constitution of Argentina|Argentine Constitution]], [[Constitution of India|Indian Constitution]], etc.
==Lex Titia and Second Triumvirate== One of the first examples of rule by decree was in the ancient [[Roman Republic]] when, after the assassination of [[Julius Caesar]] in 44 BC, his successor, Gaius Octavian ([[Augustus]]), general [[Mark Antony]] and succeeding [[pontifex maximus]] [[Aemilius Lepidus]] seized power in the [[Second Triumvirate]], officially recognized by the [[roman senate|senate]] by the [[Lex Titia]] decree. The resolution, which gave the three 'triumvirs' authoritarian powers for five years, was enacted and reinstated consecutive in 38 BC. It finally collapsed in 33/32 BC, after the downfall of Lepidus, leading to the [[Final war of the Roman Republic]] and the total collapse of republican government.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ancient.eu/Second_Triumvirate/ |title=Second Triumvirate |last=Wasson |first=Donald L. |date=18 April 2016 |website=Ancient History Encyclopedia |publisher= |access-date=14 April 2017 |quote=}}</ref>
==Reichstag Fire Decree of 28 February 1933== The most prominent example in history is the [[Reichstag Fire Decree]]. [[President of Germany (1919–1945)|German President]] [[Paul von Hindenburg]] was convinced by [[Adolf Hitler]] to issue a decree suspending basic civil rights indefinitely. As a result of this decree, [[Nazism|Nazi]] authorities were able to constitutionally suppress or imprison their opposition, which in turn paved the way for the one-party rule of the [[Third Reich]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.ushmm.org/learn/timeline-of-events/1933-1938/reichstag-fire-decree |title=Reichstag Fire Decree |last= |first= |date= |website=ushmm.org |publisher=United States Holocaust Memorial Museum |access-date=14 April 2017 |quote=}}</ref> The ensuing [[State of emergency|state of exception]], which suspended the Constitution without repealing it, lasted until the end of the Third Reich.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.opendemocracy.net/ay-e-kad-o-lu/coup-d-tat-attempt-turkey-s-reichstag-fire |title=Coup d'état attempt: Turkey’s Reichstag fire? |last=Kadıoğlu |first=Ayşe |date=16 July 2016 |website=opendemocracy.net |publisher= |access-date=14 April 2017 |quote=}}</ref> ==Decrees in non-dictatorial regimes== Some democratic leaders, such as the presidents of [[President of Mexico|Mexico]], [[President of France|France]] and [[President of Argentina|Argentina]] may rule by decree in national emergencies, subject to constitutional and other legal limitations. In the case of France this power has been used only once, by [[Charles de Gaulle]] in 1961 during the [[Algerian War]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.robinsonlibrary.com/history/france/france/20th/1958.htm |title=France in 1958 |last= |first= |date=22 June 2016 |website=robinsonlibrary.com |publisher=The Robinson Library |access-date=14 April 2017 |quote=}}</ref>
Other modern political concepts, such as the French [[decree]]s, [[Order in Council|Orders in Council]] in the British Commonwealth and American [[Executive order (United States)|executive order]]s are partially based on this notion of decrees, although they are far more limited in scope and generally subject to [[judicial review]].
===India=== During the [[Indian Emergency]] from 1975 to 1977, Prime Minister [[Indira Gandhi]] had laws passed that allowed her to rule by decree.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thehindu.com/specials/in-depth/the-emergency-imposed-by-indira-gandhi-government/article7357305.ece |title=Emergency: The Dark Age of Indian democracy |last= |first= |date=27 June 2015 |website=thehindu.com |publisher=The Hindu |access-date=14 April 2017 |quote=}}</ref>
===Ireland=== Ireland's [[Emergency Powers Act 1939|Emergency Powers Act]] allows the government to rule by decrees called ''Emergency Powers Orders'' in any aspect of national life, if the [[Oireachtas|parliament]] invokes the emergency clause in Article 28(3) of the [[Constitution of Ireland|Constitution]]. The Act however allows the [[Dáil Éireann|lower house]] to void specific EPOs in a free vote or end the state of emergency at any time.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/1939/act/28/enacted/en/print.html |title=Emergency Powers Act, 1939 |last= |first= |date=3 September 1939 |website=irishstatutebook.ie |publisher= |access-date=14 April 2017 |quote=}}</ref>
===Russia=== From 23 September<ref>[[s:ru:Указ Президента РФ от 21.09.1993 № 1400| Russian presidential decree №1400]] '''(in Russian)'''</ref> (given actual effect from 4 October after the [[1993 Russian constitutional crisis|armed disbanding]] of the [[Supreme Soviet of Russia|Supreme Soviet]]) to 12 December 1993, rule by decree ([[ukase]]s) was imposed in [[Russia]] by [[President of Russia|President]] [[Boris Yeltsin]], during transition from the [[Russian Constitution of 1978]] (which was modelled after the obsolete [[Soviet Constitution of 1977]]) to the [[Constitution of Russia|current 1993 Constitution]].
===Venezuela=== [[Venezuela]]n [[President of Venezuela|President]] [[Hugo Chávez]] was granted executive power by the [[National Assembly (Venezuela)|National Assembly]] to rule by decree multiple times throughout his tenure, passing hundreds of laws. Chávez ruled Venezuela by decree in 2000,<ref name="DAILY">{{cite news|title=Venezuela grants Chavez power to rule by decree|url=http://www.nation.co.ke/news/world/Venezuela-grants-Chavez-power-to-rule-by-decree-/-/1068/1074822/-/view/printVersion/-/h2nxp5z/-/index.html|accessdate=12 May 2016|agency=''[[Daily Nation]]''|date=18 December 2010}}</ref> 2001,<ref name="DAILY"/> 2004,<ref name="GUARDfamily">{{cite news|last1=Carroll|first1=Rory|title=A family affair|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/dec/06/chavez-family-venezuela|accessdate=12 May 2016|agency=''[[The Guardian]]''|date=5 December 2008}}</ref> 2005,<ref name="GUARDfamily"/> 2006,<ref name="GUARDfamily"/> 2007,<ref name="BBCchavezDECREE">{{cite news|title=Rule by decree passed for Chavez|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/6277379.stm|accessdate=12 May 2016|agency=[[BBC News]]|date=19 January 2007}}</ref> 2008,<ref name="DAILY"/><ref name="BBCchavezDECREE"/> 2010,<ref name="DAILY"/><ref name="CNNdecree">{{cite news|title=Hugo Chavez Fast Facts|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/12/11/world/americas/hugo-chavez---fast-facts/|accessdate=12 May 2016|agency=[[CNN]]|date=16 July 2013}}</ref> 2011<ref name="DAILY"/><ref name="CNNdecree"/> and 2012.<ref name="DAILY"/><ref name="CNNdecree"/> Between 2004 and 2006 alone, Chávez declared 18 "emergencies" to rule by decree.<ref name="GUARDfamily"/>
Chávez's successor, [[Nicolás Maduro]], has also ruled by decree multiple times since he was elected in April 2013. President Maduro has ruled Venezuela by decree for the majority of the period from 19 November 2013<ref name=WPdecree>{{cite news|last1=Diaz-Struck|first1=Emilia|last2=Forero|first2=Juan|title=Venezuelan president Maduro given power to rule by decree|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/the_americas/venezuelan-president-maduro-given-power-to-rule-by-decree/2013/11/19/af304c3c-516b-11e3-9ee6-2580086d8254_story.html|accessdate=27 April 2015|agency=''[[The Washington Post]]''|date=19 November 2013}}</ref> through 2018.<ref name=BBCdecree>{{cite news|title=Venezuela: President Maduro granted power to govern by decree|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-31899510|accessdate=27 April 2015|agency=[[BBC News]]|date=16 March 2015}}</ref><ref name=GUARDdecree>{{Cite news|title = Venezuela president declares economic emergency as inflation hits 141%|url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jan/16/venezuela-president-declares-economic-emergency-as-inflation-hits-141|newspaper = The Guardian|date = 15 January 2016|access-date = 24 February 2016|issn = 0261-3077|language = en-GB|first = Sibylla|last = Brodzinsky}}</ref><ref name=INDdecree>{{cite news|last1=Worely|first1=Will|title=Venezuela is going to shut down for a whole week because of an energy crisis|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/venezuela-is-going-to-shut-down-for-a-whole-week-because-of-an-energy-crisis-a6939246.html|accessdate=12 May 2016|agency=''[[The Independent]]''|date=18 March 2016}}</ref><ref name=DECREE8>{{cite news|last1=Kraul|first1=Chris|title=Human rights activists say many Venezuelan protesters face abusive government treatment|url=http://www.latimes.com/world/mexico-americas/la-fg-venezuela-contreras-20170517-story.html|accessdate=22 May 2017|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=17 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Gobierno extiende por décima vez el decreto de emergencia económica|url=https://www.lapatilla.com/site/2017/07/18/gobierno-extiende-por-decima-vez-el-decreto-de-emergencia-economica/|accessdate=19 July 2017|work=[[La Patilla]]|date=18 July 2017|language=es-ES}}</ref>
==Giorgio Agamben's critique of the use of decrees-law== Italian philosopher [[Giorgio Agamben]] has claimed that there has been an explosion in the use of various types of decrees (decree-law, presidential decrees, executive orders, etc.) since [[World War I]]. According to him, this is the sign of a "generalization of the [[state of exception]]".

{{Infobox philosopher |region = [[Western Philosophy]] |name = Rémi Brague |image = Paris - Rémi Brague - 1.jpg |caption = Remi Brague in 2017 |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1947|9|08}} |birth_place = [[Paris]] |school_tradition = [[Continental Philosophy]]
[[Phenomenology (philosophy)|Phenomenology]] |main_interests = {{plainlist| * [[History of Philosophy]] * [[Metaphysics]] * [[Cosmology]] * [[Political Philosophy]] * [[Philosophy of Religion]] * [[Philosophy of Law]] * [[Western Civilization]] * [[Aristotelianism]] * [[Secularity]] * [[Medieval Islamic philosophy]] * [[Medieval Jewish philosophy]] * [[Medieval Christianity]] }} |notable_ideas = {{plainlist| * The centrality of [[Romanitas]] to Western Civilization * The [[Secularism]]/[[Secularity]] distinction }} |influences = {{flatlist| * [[Aristotle]] * [[Plato]] * [[Martin Heidegger|Heidegger]] * [[Leo Strauss|Strauss]] * [[Maimonides]] * [[Al-Farabi]] * [[Thomas Aquinas|Aquinas]] }} }} '''Rémi Brague''' (born 8 September 1947) is a French historian of philosophy, specializing in the Arabic, Jewish, and Christian thought of the Middle Ages. He is professor emeritus of Arabic and religious philosophy at the [[University of Paris|Sorbonne]], and Romano Guardini chair of philosophy (emeritus) at the [[Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich]]. == Biography == Educated primarily at the [[École Normale Supérieure]] in Paris, Brague began his career as a student of Greek philosophy, interpreted in a distinctly modern key: his doctoral thesis, later published as ''Aristote et la question du monde: Essai sur le contexte cosmologique et anthropologique de l'ontologie'' (1988), developed a phenomenological account of Aristotle's conception of the world.Tom Rockmore, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=lcins1akebcC&printsec=frontcover&dq=heidegger+and+french+philosophy&hl=en&sa=X&ei=KR75Uf78AcSMyAHVloG4Dg&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=heidegger%20and%20french%20philosophy&f=false Heidegger and French Philosophy: Humanism, Anti-Humanism, and Being]'' (London: Routledge, 1995), 130. In particular, his goal was to write the book on Aristotle that [[Martin Heidegger|Heidegger]] would have written, had he not written ''[[Being and Time]].''On the role of Heideggerian [[Dasein]] in Brague’s account of Aristotle, see Sarah Broadie, Review of ''Aristote et la question du monde.'' ''Ancient Philosophy'' 13.1 (Spring, 1993): 201-204. From there, he was led to study Hebrew, in order to read the Old Testament, and Arabic in order "to read the Jewish philosopher [[Maimonides]]' ''[[The Guide for the Perplexed]]'' in its original language."[http://www.clarionreview.org/2009/10/%E2%80%9Cyellow-ants%E2%80%9D-fundamentalists-and-cowboys/ "'Yellow Ants,' Fundamentalists, and Cowboys – An interview with Rémi Brague."] ''The Clarion Review''. October 29, 2009. Since then, most of his work has taken place at the intersection of the three Abrahamic religions,A term Brague deprecates, as each religion understands Abraham, as well as its relation to Abraham, in fundamentally different ways. See ''On the God of the Christians (And on One or Two Others)'' (South Bend, IN: St. Augustine’ Press, 2013), 9-14. as they developed out of the ancient world, formed themselves in dialogue with one another, and eventually gave rise to modernity. He is the author of numerous books on classical and medieval intellectual history, religion, national identity, literature and law, and is perhaps best known in the English-speaking world for his book ''Europe, la voie romaine'' (1992), translated into English as ''Eccentric Culture: A Theory of Western Civilization'' (2009). His masterwork thus far is his trilogy on the philosophical development of law in the West, ''La Sagesse du monde: Histoire de l'expérience humaine de l'univers'' (1999), ''La Loi de Dieu. Histoire philosophique d’une alliance'' (2005), and ''Le Règne de l'homme: Genèse et échec du projet moderne'' (2015): the first two have been translated as ''The Wisdom of the World: The Human Experience of the Universe in Western Thought'' (2004) and ''The Law of God: The Philosophical History of an Idea'' (2007); the third is forthcoming under the title, ''The Kingdom of man: The Genesis and Failure of the Modern Project. ''See Paul Seaton, “Translator’s Introduction” to ''The Legitimacy of the Human'' (South Bend, IN: St. Augustine’ Press, 2017) xi. While his intellectual influences are various, Brague has developed some of the chief points of his unique account of Western intellectual history in dialogue with the controversial political theorist [[Leo Strauss]]: Brague has said that "Leo Strauss taught me that when reading a text, you must be open to the possibility that it contains different layers of meaning. All philosophical books written before the Enlightenment aim at both a wider audience and a small elite, able to understand the deeper meaning of the texts." This approach informed Brague's understanding of Maimonides and the medieval Muslim philosopher [[Al-Farabi]], among others, but he declared himself unconvinced "that it applies to the Greek philosophers" in the way Strauss has taught. "But Strauss became so convinced of his own way of interpreting texts, that he came to apply it to all sorts of books, even Cervantes''' [[Don Quixote]]''. Strauss taught me to read very carefully. But I don't consider myself a Straussian, nor do the real Straussians consider me as one of them."[http://www.clarionreview.org/2009/10/%E2%80%9Cyellow-ants%E2%80%9D-fundamentalists-and-cowboys/ "'Yellow Ants,' Fundamentalists, and Cowboys – An interview with Rémi Brague."] ''The Clarion Review'' (Oct. 29, 2009). On Brague’s view of Strauss’s Maimonides, see “Leo Strauss and Maimonides,” in ''Leo Strauss’s Thought: Toward a Critical Engagement,'' ed. Alan Udoff (Boulder, CO: Lynne Rienner, 1991), 93-114. On the kinds of texts (esp. Christian ones) to which Straussian interpretation fails to be adequate, see Brague, "Athens, Jerusalem, Mecca: Leo Strauss's 'Muslim' Understanding of Greek Philosophy,” ''Poetics Today'' 19.2 (Summer 1998): 235–259. Arguably, Brague's "Roman" view of Western Intellectual History (as enunciated in ''Eccentric Culture'') forms a kind of response to Strauss' famous emphasis on the centuries-long tension between Athens and Jerusalem: for Brague, we cannot understand this tension correctly without understanding the historic mediation of both Athens and Jerusalem through Rome.See Mark Shiffman, [http://www.mmisi.org/ma/47_02/shiffman.pdf "Neither Greek nor Jew: A Review of Remi Brague, ''Eccentric Culture'',"] ''Modern Age'' 47.2 (Spring 2005): 160–163. See also Remi Brague, "Athens—Jerusalem—Rome," ''Communio'' 40.1 (Spring 2013): 23–24. Likewise, Brague's account of Divine Law in the Western intellectual tradition (as presented in ''The Law of God'') reframes the relationship between faith and reason, the secular and the sacred, in response to Strauss' recurrent emphasis on "the Theological-Political Problem."See Christopher Morrissey, [http://bmcr.brynmawr.edu/2007/2007-09-46.html "Review of ''The Law of God'', by Remi Brague,"] ''Bryn Mawr Classical Review'' (Sep. 2009). See also Adam Kirsh, [http://www.nysun.com/arts/divine-law-and-history-remi-brague/54090/ "Divine Law and History: Remi Brague,"] ''New York Sun'' (May 9, 2007). And for Brague’s transformation of the “theologico-political problem,” see ''The Law of God,'' 2-8. Brague is the recipient of numerous awards, including honors by both the [[French National Centre for Scientific Research]] and the [[Academy of Moral and Political Science]]. In 2009, he received both the [[Josef Pieper]] Prize [http://www.franz-hitze-haus.de/index.php?cat_id=20380 "Rémi Brague – Preisträger des Josef Pieper Preises 2009"] ''Akademie Franz Hitze Haus'' (2009) and the Grand prix de philosophie de l'[[Académie française]],[http://www.academie-francaise.fr/remi-brague "Rémi Brague: Prix de l'Académie française"] ''Académie française'' (2009) and on Saturday, 28 September 2012, it was announced that Brague, along with [[Brian E. Daley]], would be awarded the 2012 [[Ratzinger Prize]] for Theology.[http://www.zenit.org/en/articles/ratzinger-prize-awarded-to-philosopher-remi-brague-and-historian-fr-brian-daley "Ratzinger Prize Awarded to Philosopher Remi Brague and Historian Fr. Brian Daley."] ''Zenit.org'' (Sep. 28, 2012) In 2013, he was named a Chevalier de l'Ordre National de la [[Légion d'honneur]].[http://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/affichTexte.do;jsessionid=6F6BEB4960D90C894B13DAD8796A3757.tpdjo11v_1?cidTexte=JORFTEXT000026871328&dateTexte=&oldAction=rechJO&categorieLien=id "Décret du 31 décembre 2012 portant promotion et nomination"] ==References== {{Reflist}} == Works == Books and Edited Volumes in French (and other languages): * ''Sur la religion.''
